text: from the heights of sprinting for his
country at last summer's Commonwealth
Games
Jimmy thunka says the day since have
seen him hit rock bottom
living rough on the streets of London
and being arrested by the police
so Jimmy tell me what had been like
living where have you been sleeping well
obviously being in the park and bosses
moving up and down because I don't have
anywhere to sleep
he had already been orphaned by Sierra
Leone's Civil War then while competing
in Glasgow Jimmy discovered that his
adoptive family had died victims of the
Ebola virus
he decided to outstay his visa and not
to fly home with his team there's
nothing like anything like athletics or
the thinking on insulin because the
outbreak of the disease and also I'd
have a family gear that would support me
for me to continue my athletic career
his story has touched many Richard dent
has set up a crowdfunding website to
help someone he'd never even met until
now so far we've raised about just over
22,000 last time I looked it's about
1,200 people have donated from the UK
but all over the world as well and lots
of people have sent really positive
messages as well for Jimmy and and
really sympathize what he's been through
Richard hopes the money will help pay
for athletics training here in the UK
and Jimmy has applied for asylum but his
fate lies not with the kindness of
strangers
but with the home office it will
determine whether or not it's safe for
him to return to the country he
represented with such pride just a few
months ago John McGuire BBC News London
